title: Eiffel Tower, Paris, France
notes: Steel art. Tall, noticeable from any place in Paris, landmark and significant icon of the city. This Paris sunset holds a particular place in my travel voyages. Stitched strong to my memories, the sunset I witnessed sitting across the lawn in front of the tower, having few cold ones, beats any of my southern californian sunsets.
alt: Sunset at Eiffel Tower in Paris, France

title: Boston, Massachusetts
notes: Home ♥️♥️♥️
alt: Otter Cliffs, Acadia National Park in Maine

title: Seattle, Washington
notes: Seattle happened by chance. I got enough out of Boston, got myself a new job in the city, which made me pack my bags and make the big move across the country. Seattle has a reputation of being gloomy, which is true for the most part. Nevertheless, the new home has a lot to offer and I've started liking it. To the new beginnings...

title: Public Market of Seattle, Washington
notes: Commencing my Seattle photography adventures, the first thing I had to witness was the popular Public Market. It is one of the few authentic farmer's markets in the United States. This is a working market that doubles as a tourist attraction. It is filled with food and flower stalls. I particularly enjoyed seeing the catch of the day in the Fish Market. Note that I call this a 'working marketing' before I alluded to it being a place tourists might enjoy. Pike has a lot to offer and is a nice blend of 'real' and 'attraction. While you are there, don't forget to look for the hidden urban garden tucked away in an alley ;)

title: Pike Place Market of Seattle, Washington
notes: Pike Place Market is filled with food and flower stalls. This hub of delicious scents, delectable eats and delightful personalities attracts nine million visitors a year.
alt: Pike Place Market of Seattle, Washington

title: Flower Stalls, Pike Place Market, Seattle, Washington
notes: Pike Place Market is filled with food and flower stalls. If you happen to visit the Pike Place Market early in the day, you get to see these flower stalls in all of its full capacity. Flowers so fresh and cheap, you right away want to get a bouquet for your loved ones.
alt: Flower Stalls, Pike Place Market, Seattle, Washington

title: First Starbucks, Seattle, Washington
notes: I had to visit the Original Starbucks, located near the waterfront in Seattle’s Pike Place Market, which famously displays the modest 45-year-old sign. This Starbucks is where it all began. The line may be crazy long, the coffee is the same as any other Starbucks, but you go there for the experience. It was one of the most surreal experience to hear the history of the company and order a drink from the very first Starbucks.

title: Yarmouth, Cape Cod
notes: Cape Cod is one of my favorite leisure destination. Every trip I've made to Cape Cod has always been memorable. The sunsets at Gray's Beach at Yarmouth are one the most spectacular events I have witnessed while living on East Coast. Definitely a hidden Cape Cod gem.
alt: Gray's Beach at Yarmouth in Cape Cod, Massachusetts

title: Parker River National Wildlife Refuge, Massachusetts
notes: Located along the northeast coast of Massachusetts, Parker River National Wildlife Refuge has special significance and value to migratory birds. This photograph is during one of the many birding adventutes I did during my years in Boston catching the glimpses of wildlife.
alt: Birding Adventure at Parker River National Wildlife Refuge, Massachusetts

title: Deer Island in Boston, Massachusetts
notes: Deer Island has been one of the places that is stitched in my core memory. I have always loved a good sunrise, and have often went distance to catch a good one. When I lived back in Boston, catching a good sunrise at Deer Island was one of the many favorite things I did frequently.

title: Cape Cod, Massachusetts
notes: Sandwich in Cape Cod, Massachusetts has been one of my other favorite places around the Cape Cod region in Massachusetts. This little boardwalk starts from nowhere and is a beautiful spot to stroll above the marsh and eventually end up on a lovely beach with dunes and protected areas for endangered birds’ nesting habitats.

title: Otter Cliffs, Acadia National Park in Maine
notes: One of the coldest and finest sunrise I have witnessed so far. This is from Otter Cliff inside Acadia National Park during the month of January. It was cold enough that my phone's battery died in few minutes. Witnessing the sun coming out in that temperature, standing in 2 layers of warm jackets trying to keep my hands warm enough and holding the camera steady enough to get one nice shot, one hell of an adventure it was. Glad that picture turned out to be a good one in the end.
alt: Otter Cliffs, Acadia National Park in Maine

title: Acadia National Park, Maine
notes: One of the coldest and finest sunrise I have witnessed so far. This is from Otter Cliff inside Acadia National Park during the month of January. It was cold enough that my phone's battery died in few minutes. Witnessing the sun coming out in that temperature, standing in 2 layers of warm jackets trying to keep my hands warm enough and holding the camera steady enough to get one nice shot, one hell of an adventure it was. Glad that picture turned out to be a good one in the end.
alt: Otter Cliffs, Acadia National Park in Maine

title: First Light
notes: Cadillac Mountain gave me the most beautiful sunrise of my life in 2017. Cadillac Mountain is one of the first places in USA to witness a sunrise. I woke up so insanely early and sat in the cold until that sun rose. It was beyond worth it. The anticipation of waking up early, feeling the morning chill sink into your bones as you wait, and the excitement of the horizon changing colors is like nothing else.
alt: Sunrise at Cadillac Mountain in Acadia National Park

title: Bar Harbor, Maine
notes: One of the coldest and finest sunrise I have witnessed so far. This is from Otter Cliff inside Acadia National Park during the month of January. It was cold enough that my phone's battery died in few minutes. Witnessing the sun coming out in that temperature, standing in 2 layers of warm jackets trying to keep my hands warm enough and holding the camera steady enough to get one nice shot, one hell of an adventure it was. Glad that picture turned out to be a good one in the end.
alt: Otter Cliffs, Acadia National Park in Maine

title: Mount Rainier, Washington
notes: An active volcano, Mount Rainier is the most glaciated peak in the contiguous U.S.A., spawning five major rivers. At a height of 14,410 feet, Mount Rainier is the highest volcanic peak in the contiguous United States. Because of the unpredictable weather climate in the state of washington, you hardly get to see the mountain in all of its glory, but on those couple of clear days when you get to see the mountain, you realize the sheer beauty of it. I have been eyeing to catch this beauty ever since I have moved to PNW - few failed drives where weather was not in my favor, but this one was totally worth it.

title: Reflection Lake, Mount Rainier, Washington
notes: The views of Mt Rainier from reflection lakes are legendary and with good reason. This is one of the most picturesque area in Mount Rainier National Park. Try to catch the lake in the early morning or evening when the water is still.  If the sky is clear you’ll have an excellent chance to view Mount Rainier reflecting in these beautiful subalpine lakes.

title: Picture Lake, Washington
notes: Picture Lake is the most incredible sight I've seen in the entire of Washington. Located in Northern Washington, Picture Lake is about a 3 hour drive from Seattle. With Mount Shuksan in the background and the wildflowers in the foreground, Picture lake is, well, as pretty as, a post card picture. The location is almost always full of people. I had to wait for 30 minutes for the people to clear up the space before I could capture it.

title: Mount Baker, Washington
notes: Mount Baker is a 10,781 ft active glacier-covered andesitic stratovolcano in the Cascade Volcanic Arc and the North Cascades of Washington. This was one of the bucketlist in my attempt to capture all the PNW mountains. The drive is long and crooked, but it was so worth it. Witnessing the sun setting down, and the mountain shining bright, I forgot all my miseries.

title: Mount Shuksan, Washington
notes: Another day, another bucketlist Mountain. Right at the Artist Point, Mount Shuksan is one of North America’s most iconic peaks. Situated on the western flank of the rugged North Cascades National Park, the mountain is capped by glaciers and surrounded by picturesque alpine lakes and meadows. Seeing that glacier up so close, and witnessing the sun rays falling all over it, it dazzles you right at the first sight. Mount Shuksan is my most favorite mountain in PWN.

title: Cape Flattery, Washington
notes: The furthest northwest tip of the contiguous United State, Cape Flattery has been on my bucketlist even before I moved to PNW. Cape Flattery provides a dramatic backdrop to a surprisingly accessible hike. The drive was insane long, but the views make it all worth it. The trail starts in the lush forest, and quickly takes you on an easy boardwalk hike and in few minutes you are witnessing the majestic North West Pacific Ocean coastline. Unbeatable views all around 180 degrees.

title: Cape Cod
notes: The furthest southest tip of the Massachusetts, United State, Cape Code has been on my bucketlist and of the most soughtful location. Cape Code provides a dramatic backdrop to a surprisingly accessible parts to Atlantic Ocean. Th panaromic views and sunsets make the trip always worth it.
